content.title: Cardiac Tamponade
content.summary: Cardiac tamponade is a life-threatening condition in which pericardial fluid accumulation causes compression of cardiac chambers, impaired diastolic filling, reduced cardiac output, and hemodynamic collapse. It requires urgent recognition and emergent pericardiocentesis or surgical drainage.
key_points: Beck's triad: hypotension, jugular venous distension, muffled heart sounds (seen in acute tamponade)
Pulsus paradoxus >10 mmHg (inspiratory SBP drop) is highly sensitive for tamponade
Echocardiography shows RA collapse in late diastole and RV collapse in early diastole
Rate of fluid accumulation matters more than volume - rapidly accumulating effusions cause tamponade with <200mL
Emergent pericardiocentesis is life-saving; echo-guided subxiphoid approach is standard
Electrical alternans on ECG indicates large effusion with swinging heart
content.statement: Cardiac tamponade represents a clinical-hemodynamic continuum from pericardial effusion to circulatory collapse. The diagnosis is clinical, supported by echocardiographic findings, and requires emergent drainage. The key pathophysiologic concept is equalization of intracardiac diastolic pressures due to external compression.

explanation.intuition: The pericardium is a relatively stiff sac. When fluid accumulates, the intrapericardial pressure rises. Once it equals or exceeds right atrial pressure, cardiac filling is impaired. Inspiration normally increases venous return to the right heart, but in tamponade this occurs at the expense of left heart filling (ventricular interdependence), causing pulsus paradoxus.
explanation.key_insight: The rate of fluid accumulation determines clinical presentation: rapidly accumulating effusions (trauma, aortic dissection) cause tamponade with small volumes, while slowly accumulating effusions (malignancy, uremia) allow pericardial stretch and may reach >1L before hemodynamic compromise.
explanation.technical_details: Echocardiographic signs in order of sensitivity: (1) RA collapse in late diastole (most sensitive), (2) RV collapse in early diastole (more specific), (3) IVC plethora without respiratory variation, (4) >25% mitral E velocity respiratory variation, (5) Swinging heart with large effusion. Hemodynamic catheterization shows equalization of diastolic pressures (RA = RVEDP = PCWP ± 5mmHg).

definitions_glossary.cardiac_tamponade: Life-threatening compression of cardiac chambers by pericardial fluid causing hemodynamic compromise
definitions_glossary.becks_triad: Classic triad of acute tamponade: hypotension, JVD, muffled heart sounds (insensitive in subacute)
definitions_glossary.pulsus_paradoxus: Exaggerated inspiratory decrease in systolic BP >10mmHg due to ventricular interdependence
definitions_glossary.pericardial_effusion: Abnormal accumulation of fluid in pericardial space; may be transudative or exudative
definitions_glossary.pericardiocentesis: Needle aspiration of pericardial fluid, typically via subxiphoid echo-guided approach
definitions_glossary.ventricular_interdependence: Phenomenon where filling of one ventricle compromises filling of other in tamponade
definitions_glossary.ra_diastolic_collapse: Inward motion of RA free wall during diastole indicating elevated pericardial pressure
definitions_glossary.rv_diastolic_collapse: Inward motion of RV free wall in early diastole, more specific for tamponade
definitions_glossary.electrical_alternans: Beat-to-beat alternation in QRS amplitude due to heart swinging in large effusion
definitions_glossary.pericardial_window: Surgical creation of opening between pericardium and pleura/peritoneum for drainage
definitions_glossary.ivc_plethora: Dilated IVC (>2.1cm) without inspiratory collapse indicating elevated RA pressure
definitions_glossary.equalization_of_pressures: RA, RV diastolic, PCWP, and LV diastolic pressures converge in tamponade

pathophysiology.mechanism: Pericardial fluid accumulation increases intrapericardial pressure. When this exceeds RA pressure, venous return and cardiac filling are compromised. Both ventricles share a fixed total volume (ventricular interdependence), so inspiration-augmented right heart filling reduces left heart filling, causing pulsus paradoxus and reduced cardiac output.
key_pathways: Pericardial fluid accumulation → increased intrapericardial pressure
Intrapericardial pressure exceeds RA pressure → impaired venous return
Impaired diastolic filling → reduced stroke volume and cardiac output
Compensatory tachycardia and vasoconstriction initially maintain BP
pathophysiology.clinical_significance: Tamponade is a medical emergency with near 100% mortality if untreated. Even small volumes (100-200mL) can cause tamponade if rapid accumulation (e.g., cardiac perforation). Pericardiocentesis can be life-saving with as little as 30-50mL fluid removal.

signs: Elevated JVP with absent Y descent
clinical_features.becks_triad_sensitivity: Present in only 10-40% of cases; more common in acute surgical tamponade

echocardiographic_findings.ra_collapse: Inversion of RA free wall during late diastole (>1/3 cardiac cycle = specific)
echocardiographic_findings.rv_collapse: Inversion of RV free wall in early diastole; highly specific
echocardiographic_findings.respiratory_variation: >25% decrease in mitral E velocity or >40% increase in tricuspid E on inspiration
echocardiographic_findings.effusion_size: Variable - chronic effusions can be massive; acute can be small

initial_stabilization: Avoid positive pressure ventilation if possible (reduces venous return)
IV fluid bolus (temporizing measure to increase filling pressure)
Avoid vasodilators and diuretics (can precipitate cardiovascular collapse)

pericardiocentesis.technique: 18-gauge needle, 30-45° angle toward left shoulder, continuous aspiration
pericardiocentesis.success_marker: Even 30-50mL removal can dramatically improve hemodynamics

definitive_treatment.catheter_drainage: Leave pigtail catheter for recurrent effusions
definitive_treatment.pericardial_window: Surgical drainage to pleural or peritoneal space for recurrent effusions
definitive_treatment.pericardiectomy: Complete pericardial stripping for recurrent tamponade or constrictive pericarditis

etiology_specific_treatment.malignant: Systemic chemotherapy, intrapericardial chemotherapy, or radiation
etiology_specific_treatment.infectious: Antibiotics; surgical drainage for purulent pericarditis

skos.definition: A life-threatening condition characterized by compression of cardiac chambers by pericardial fluid accumulation, resulting in impaired diastolic filling, reduced cardiac output, and potential hemodynamic collapse

learning_objectives: Explain the pathophysiology of cardiac tamponade including ventricular interdependence
Recognize clinical and echocardiographic signs of cardiac tamponade
Differentiate tamponade from other causes of obstructive shock
Demonstrate understanding of pulsus paradoxus mechanism and measurement
Describe indications and technique for emergent pericardiocentesis
Identify causes of pericardial effusion that may lead to tamponade
clinical_pearls: Rate of accumulation > volume: 100mL rapidly can cause tamponade; 1L slowly may not
Beck's triad is insensitive (10-40%); rely on echo and pulsus paradoxus
RA collapse is most sensitive; RV collapse is more specific for tamponade
Avoid positive pressure ventilation and diuretics - both reduce preload
Even 30-50mL removal at pericardiocentesis can be life-saving
Low-pressure tamponade can occur in hypovolemic patients - maintain high suspicion
Electrical alternans is specific but insensitive (seen in ~20% of large effusions)

specialty_boards.cardiology: High yield - echo recognition, procedural competence, hemodynamic interpretation
specialty_boards.emergency_medicine: Critical - rapid diagnosis and management in shock

common_misconceptions: Beck's triad is always present (only 10-40% of cases)
Large effusions always cause tamponade (rate matters more than size)
Positive pressure ventilation helps (actually harmful by reducing preload)
Pulsus paradoxus is diagnostic (also seen in severe asthma, COPD, constrictive pericarditis)

Understand ventricular interdependence and pulsus paradoxus

RA collapse most sensitive; RV collapse more specific
Avoid PPV and diuretics in tamponade
